Package io.crums.sldg.demo.jurno

Class Journal

java.lang.Object
io.crums.sldg.demo.jurno.Journal
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.io.Closeable, java.lang.AutoCloseable
public class Journal
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.io.Closeable
A text file journaled with a ledger. The hash of every (ledgerable) line in a journal corresponds to a (non-beacon) row in a ledger. Line numbers, like ledger row numbers, are 1-based.

Limits

This implementation can manage a maximum of 2,147,483,647 lines.

Concurrent Writes

BAD. Everything breaks: don't do this. On the plus side, the next time you try to read the data, you'll know you broke it.

See Also:
Journal.State

  • Nested Class Summary

    Nested Classes
    Modifier and Type Class Description
    static class  Journal.State
    The state of a journal is the state of its text file vs the state of the ledger that records its history.

    • getState

      public Journal.State getState()
      Returns the state of the instance, or null if neither updated nor dry-runned.

      State of Accessor Methods

      The return values of the methods
      • getLines(),
      • getTextLineCount(),
      • getForkLineNumber(), and
      • getForkTextLineNumber()
      are significant only if this method does not return null.

    • getTextLineCount

      public int getTextLineCount()
      Returns the number of lines in the text file. The number of ledgerable lines may be fewer. For example, blank lines typically don't count.
      See Also:
      getLines()

    • getLines

    • getForkTextLineNumber

      public int getForkTextLineNumber()
      Returns the line number in the text at which the file has forked from its historical ledger, or zero if the state is not forked.

    • lastValidLedgerRow

      public int lastValidLedgerRow() throws java.lang.IllegalStateException
      Returns the highest row number (includes beacon rows) in the ledger that matches the journaled text file.
      Returns:
      ≥ 0
      Throws:
      java.lang.IllegalStateException

    • lastValidLedgeredLine

      public int lastValidLedgeredLine() throws java.lang.IllegalStateException
      Returns the highest ledgered line number in the text file that matches the backing ledger. This filters beacon rows from the accounting (so you don't have to).
      Returns:
      ≥ 0
      Throws:
      java.lang.IllegalStateException

      public void dryRun()

    • getLedgerableLines

      public java.util.List<java.lang.String> getLedgerableLines​(java.util.List<java.lang.Integer> lineNumbers)
      Returns the given ledgered (or more accurately, ledgerable) line numbers from the text file. Since some lines may be skipped (i.e. blank or comment lines), ledgerable-line numbers seldom match one-to-one with actual line numbers in the text.

      Note the file must be traversed sequentially to the last line number. If this is a big number (and therefore the file is big), this might take a second.

      Parameters:
      lineNumbers - strictly ascending list of positive ledgerable line numbers
      Returns:
      read-only list of verbatim lines from the text (with trailing new-line chars trimmed, of course)
      Throws:
      java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if lineNumbers is empty, not ascending, has dups, or specifies a non-existent line (i.e. not positive or beyond the last line in the file)

    • canonicalizeLine

      protected java.lang.String canonicalizeLine​(java.lang.String line)
      Canonicalizes the given non-null line and returns it. Some lines, per the parsing rules of the subclass, may count for naught: in such cases, null is returned.

      The base implementation trims leading and trailing whitespace from the given line: empty lines don't count and so are returned as null.

    • newLineProc

      protected java.util.function.Consumer<java.lang.String> newLineProc()
      Returns the new line processor. The returned object adds a new row to the ledger on each invocation.

    • verifyLineFunc

      protected java.util.function.BiPredicate<java.lang.String,​java.lang.Long> verifyLineFunc()
      Returns the line verification function.

    • verifyLine

      protected final boolean verifyLine​(java.lang.String line, long rowNumber, java.security.MessageDigest digest)
